title: Machine Learning Notebook 👀
text:
This website will be our Machine Learning course, where we explore various statistical and machine learning models using the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) 2023 dataset. Through this course, I learned to implement and understand different modeling techniques using the tidymodels framework in R.

What You’ll Find Here

About Me: A little bit about me and my research interests.
The Dataset: Information about my primary dataset and the research question I am trying to answer.
Model Implementations: Hands-on examples of different models to answer the question:

Logistic Regression
Lasso Regression
Decision Trees
Random Forest
K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

title: Machine Learning Course Portfolio
text:
This website serves as a comprehensive portfolio of our Machine Learning course, where we explore various statistical and machine learning models using the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) 2023 dataset. Through this course, we’ll learn to implement and understand different modeling techniques using the tidymodels framework in R.



Course Notes: Detailed explanations of concepts and methodologies
Model Implementations: Hands-on examples of different models:

Logistic Regression
Lasso Regression
Decision Trees
Random Forest
K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

YRBS 2023 Dataset: Information about our primary dataset
Interactive Visualizations: Results and insights from our models




Navigate through the different sections using the menu above. Each model section contains: - Model explanation - Implementation code - Results and interpretations - Visualizations - Key takeaways
Feel free to explore and learn!

title: YRBS 2023 Dataset
text:
The Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) is a national survey that monitors health-related behaviors among high school students. The 2023 dataset provides valuable insights into various aspects of youth health and behavior.



Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Year: 2023
Target Population: High school students
Sample Size: [Add sample size]
Geographic Coverage: [Add coverage information]




The dataset includes information on various health-related behaviors:

Demographic Variables

Age
Gender
Race/Ethnicity
Grade level

Health Behaviors

Physical activity
Nutrition
Sleep patterns
Substance use

Mental Health

Stress levels
Depression
Anxiety
Suicidal thoughts

Risk Behaviors

Tobacco use
Alcohol consumption
Drug use
Sexual behavior

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic regression is a statistical model that…

Model Overview
Logistic regression is used when the dependent variable is binary (0/1, Yes/No, True/False). The model estimates the probability of the dependent variable being 1 given the independent variables.


Implementation

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic regression is a statistical model that…


Logistic regression is used when the dependent variable is binary (0/1, Yes/No, True/False). The model estimates the probability of the dependent variable being 1 given the independent variables.




library(tidymodels)

── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels 1.3.0 ──


✔ broom        1.0.8     ✔ recipes      1.3.0
✔ dials        1.4.0     ✔ rsample      1.3.0
✔ dplyr        1.1.4     ✔ tibble       3.2.1

✔ parsnip      1.3.1     ✔ workflowsets 1.1.0
✔ purrr        1.0.4     ✔ yardstick    1.3.2


── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels_conflicts() ──
✖ purrr::discard() masks scales::discard()
✖ dplyr::filter()  masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()     masks stats::lag()
✖ recipes::step()  masks stats::step()

✖ dplyr::lag()        masks stats::lag()

title: About Me
text:
I am Catalina Canizares
I am a researcher dedicated to preventing suicidal behaviors in adolescents. Currently, I am a postdoctoral researcher at NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development. My work spans several projects, including intervention programs for preventing suicide attempts and developing data structures to deepen our understanding of adolescent suicide attempts and ideation.
I am deeply invested in data science, applying machine learning techniques to reveal insights and patterns in suicide-related data. As a primary user of R, I am committed to sharing my knowledge and experiences with the broader community.
I am also dedicated to ensuring clarity and reproducibility in my work, using tools like Quarto and RMarkdown. This approach ensures that my research is trustworthy and easily followed by others.
If I could describe myself using three emojis I would select: 🏝🇨🇴🐈

title: About
text:
This Machine Learning course is designed to provide students with hands-on experience in implementing various statistical and machine learning models using R and the tidymodels framework. We’ll be working with the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) 2023 dataset to explore real-world applications of these models.



Understand fundamental machine learning concepts
Implement various models using tidymodels
Learn to evaluate and compare model performance
Develop skills in data visualization and interpretation
Create reproducible analyses and reports





Logistic Regression

Binary classification
Model interpretation
Performance metrics

Lasso Regression

Feature selection
Regularization
Model complexity

Decision Trees

Tree-based learning
Decision rules
Model visualization

Random Forest

Ensemble methods
Bagging
Feature importance

K-Nearest Neighbors

Distance metrics
Parameter tuning
Non-parametric learning






R programming language
tidymodels framework
tidyverse for data manipulation
ggplot2 for visualization
Quarto for documentation
